column4: Hi, could anyone please tell me the main differences between recovery mode and normal mode? Feel free to talk to me directly if you like.
recovery mode boots you to a simple root prompt in single user mode, no X or anything is started

Yes, but are there any other differences? At the moment my system freezes in normal mode, but i I head into recovery and then start gdm manually I don't have any problems. I'm just trying to track down the problem but finding it very tough as no errors appear in syslog!
it probably freezes due to a broken service that is not started in single user mode. doesn't it give you a clue? when does it freeze?
and what text is on the screen when it freezes?
that sounds like a bad bug. I'd check the log files /var/log/syslog for starters
most of the time broken drivers are causing that behavior. maybe some module that is normally loaded isn't in single user mode

There's nothing obvious in syslog - certainly no errors. Like I said, it always happens at a slightly different time, so the logs always look slightly different before the crash. There's no obvious common event.
can you lsmod in single user mode and then in normal mode and compare them?
maybe that will help you determine the bad module if that is the case
Aaah yes, lsmod lists the loaded modules doesn't it? Ok, another good idea! I think my common sense must have jumped ship! Thanks.
I suppose the main problem will be doing lsmod before it freezes. I don't know if I'll have enough time.
you can disable the gdm startup
in single user mode install rcconf and run it and disable gdm
Excellent - thanks. I (obviously) didn't know that could be done. Right... I'll go and give this a try. Thanks again!
